#Text=Read
#Text=Plato ’s Gorgias
#Text=This how-to instruction set will guide any student , either at the high school or undergraduate level , on reading Plato ’s Gorgias .
#Text=As a student of any level in English one will run into classical texts at some point .
#Text=Plato ’s Gorgias is a text that is relevant to the field of Rhetoric and Composition Studies , as it debated the uses and misuses of rhetoric as a verbal/written genre .
#Text=The following sections ( supplies , before you read , while you ’re reading , and after you read ) will slowly guide the reader of this how-to in understanding the text at hand .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Pre-Reading for a Platonic Dialogue
#Text=Go to a workspace with all of the supplies .
#Text=This will limit the number of times you will have to stop reading the text .
#Text=The dialogue in the Gorgias is unfamiliar and therefore may require you to re-read and focus .
#Text=This is why having a workspace that is comfortable for you will help to limit frustration and distractions .
#Text=When choosing a workspace pick somewhere that you are able to study and focus .
#Text=This could be done in a library , home or coffee shop where ever is best for you .
#Text=Practice Active Reading Strategies .
#Text=Active reading is employing different methods to help understand a text before and while you read .
#Text=Using active reading methods before you begin reading will help to ease the frustration that can follow reading a difficult text .
#Text=Here are a few links for more information on pre-reading strategies
#Text=Study Guides and Strategies
#Text=7 Pre-Reading Strategies that Increase Comprehension
#Text=Understand why the text is valuable for your field ( English , Rhetoric and Composition , Communications , Media studies , Philosophy ... ) .
#Text=Plato ’s Gorgias is important because it is a core text use to define the function of Rhetoric .
#Text=As a student studying in the field of English as a BA or an MA , this understanding is fundamental to how the genre is understood .
#Text=Many scholars use this text as a way to argue within their own works .
#Text=If you have a good base understanding of this text , you will be able to read others with less frustration .
#Text=Especially , if you are a student in the field of Rhetoric and Composition Studies as the piece helped to define the field in which you study .
#Text=Reading Strategies for the Gorgias
#Text=Do background research into the Ancient Greek Scene .
#Text=This should be the history the scholar Plato and settings , themes , and characters of Gorgias to gain context via a quick online search .
#Text=This will help you to read the text easier because you will be familiar with this writing style , base themes and limit frustration at unfamiliar concepts and jargon .
#Text=For example , virtue and the functions of rhetoric are themes discussed within this text .
#Text=Write focus questions about why the concepts or ideas in this text matters .
#Text=This can be typically 3-4 questions bases on your research you have conducted on the text .
#Text=These will help you to center your reading of this text .
#Text=Some sample questions you may ask are :
#Text=What take does Plato have in terms of the use of rhetoric in society ?
#Text=What other characters are involved ?
#Text=Do they have the same viewpoints as Plato or are they different ?
#Text=How does Plato differ from the sophists ?
#Text=Does Plato 's position on rhetoric make sense in modern studies of rhetoric ?
#Text=Take notes in the margins .
#Text=They can come in the form of comments or questions , but actively engaging with the text allows you to retain what you are reading .
#Text=Mark any unfamiliar jargon while reading .
#Text=Look up unfamiliar jargon after reading the text completely as this will help to keep a focus on reading .
#Text=This will limit frustration because of unfamiliar words .
#Text=Some unfamiliar jargon that you may come across could include :
#Text=sophist
#Text=harangue
#Text=techne
#Text=oratory/orator
#Text=nomos
#Text=Mark any main themes around the function/defining of Rhetoric .
#Text=In this piece , Plato is discussing , through Socrates , the meaning , and uses of rhetoric .
#Text=Socrates is engaged in an argument with Gorgias who believed that rhetoric is the art of persuasion .
#Text=Gorgias is a sophist .
#Text=The sophists are teachers that instruct others to make a living , and not just for the pleasure of having knowledge .
#Text=The art of persuasion that Gorgias is speaking is used to make money and other reasons that Socrates deems immoral .
#Text=Therefore , Socrates deems rhetoric as a skill , unlike philosophy which is an art form .
#Text=This piece is one of the first known sightings of the word “ rhetoric ” and it gives an insight into the functions and uses of rhetoric as a genre .
#Text=Take notes on characters stances .
#Text=This piece is centered around a debate going on between Socrates and Gorgas about what function of rhetoric .
#Text=All characters involved have different stances on the definition of rhetoric .
#Text=This idea will inform your core understanding of the meaning of Plato ’s Gorgias .
#Text=The characters you will most likely come across are :
#Text=Socrates
#Text=Gorgias
#Text=Polus
#Text=Callicles
#Text=Chaerephon
#Text=Reflecting on Reading the Gorgias
#Text=Look up any jargon you did not understand .
#Text=Answer the focus questions that you wrote before reading .
#Text=Being able to answer these questions can assess how much is taken away from the work from the initial read .
#Text=Ask yourself how this text relates to the goals of the course you are currently enrolled in or how it relates to other texts you have read so far .
#Text=Assess your understanding of the text .
#Text=Did you understand the work ?
#Text=Remember that this text is not easy to understand and can be confusing for first time readers .
#Text=But , this is okay and expected , because reading as a process is not linear , but recursive .
#Text=Meaning that it may take more than one attempt to begin understanding a text .
#Text=Reread the text .
#Text=Take your time and read through the piece once more to help gain a better understanding of the material .
#Text=Read additional summaries .
#Text=If you are still having issues understanding this text go back and read a summary or book review .
#Text=Talk it over with others in your class .
#Text=Ask your teacher or professor some questions regarding the text to help gain some insight .
